page.title: 07PLACE NAMES
page.content: Place name evidence in a 50 km squared area centred on Penpont and Thornhill suggests many peoples have settled here in the past. In addition to the many, more modern, English and Anglo-Scots names 35 Gaelic, 11 Norse and 6 names from Celtic languages other than Gaelic were found. Most hills and names in higher locations tend to be Gaelic- Tibbers (Tiobar-a well), Auchenbainzie (Achad na Baine-field untilled), Druid Hall (Druid-thrush) prounced locally Droodall. Norse names are mainly confined to the valley floors-Langmyre (Langr-long Myrr-bog), Mullach (Muli-promontary), Byreholm (Byr-farm holmr-small island). Penpont, Keir and Tynron defy translation directly into Gaelic but are clearly derived from ancient Celtic languages.
